text:
Dear Sir,

who I am is of very little interest to anyone but what you may want to know or anyone else enough to inquire about me.

I was born in Glasgow, Scotland, on July 5, 1866, in the parish of St. Andrew's, in the county of Renfrewshire. I moved to Canada in 1870 at the age of 14 years old.

The circumstances of my coming to Canada were quite unique. I was sent away from home when I was nine years old by my parents, who wished me to be educated in Canada. I arrived in Canada in 1879 and have lived here ever since.

I came to Canada because I wanted to be free from the responsibilities of working on a farm. I wanted to be able to earn my own living.

I have worked as a laborer, a farmer, and a teacher. I have also been involved in various community activities.

I am now retired and enjoy spending my time with my family and friends.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Stamp]
The manager,

Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon.

Dear Sir,

Who I am is of very little interest to anyone but what you may want from me or any other enough to convey the meaning of my communication: I was born in Glasgow, Scotland, on June 6, 1865, of Scottish parentage of the old Cromarty clan. They moved to a farm near Beamsley, Indiana, in 1870. The next year of my life was spent there in a harsh climate. The discipline of the Catholic Church was strict by today's standards. I was nine years of age when I attended school for two years at home under the guidance of my parents. I then attended a school in the district, as far as I could go, for two years, spending the summer months working on the farm. In 1889, I went to school in Chicago, Illinois, where I studied for two years, obtaining a diploma in business administration. After graduation, I returned to the farm and worked as a farmer until 1906. I then moved to the city and became involved in the business world. I have always been interested in history and have written extensively on the subject. I am now retired and living in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

[Stamp]
The Manager,
Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to you in response to your request for information regarding my family history. I was born in Ireland on December 5, 1865, to parents named John and Mary Smith. My father was a farmer and my mother was a homemaker. We lived in a small village called County Cork.

In 1870, my family moved to Canada, settling in the province of Saskatchewan. We arrived by train and settled in a small town called Regina. We purchased land and began farming. We had six children, including myself.

In 1889, my father died and we were left to manage the farm on our own. We worked hard and eventually saved enough money to purchase more land. We expanded our farm and became successful farmers.

In 1906, my mother died and I took over the management of the farm. I continued to work hard and expanded our operations. We became known as successful farmers in the area.

I hope this information is helpful to you. If you need any further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Stamp]
The Manager,
Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to you in response to your request for information regarding my family history. I was born in 1865 in the province of Saskatchewan, Canada. My parents were farmers who lived in a small town near Regina. They had nine children, including myself.

In 1889, I moved to the city of Regina to attend university. After graduating, I worked as an accountant for a local bank. In 1900, I married my wife, Jane, and we had three children together.

In 1920, I retired from my job and moved to a small farm near Moose Jaw. I spent the rest of my life farming and raising cattle. I died in 1940 at the age of 75.

I hope this information is helpful to you. If you need any further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Stamp]

The "Boy's Brown" for nine weeks prior to the Samuel Eaton's of 1896 had been its additional columns to Winkler's "Brown" for $5.00. The editor of the "Brown" of that day commented that $5.00 was about enough to be charging them the price of the columns. If any one could raise $5.00 worth of a newspaper while the Government was in power, the Griller should try again at it, saying it had nothing to lose by it except perhaps the printing office. We then pulled back and established the printing office in Marion. About six months later we moved to a new place, but it has changed hands several times. The Griller opened an enormous amount of business in 1897-1898, and I worked very hard, and the publication of newspapers continued until the year 1900 when I went out on my own account.

In the year 1898, the Presbyterian Church organized itself as a system of organs, which included "History of the Reformation," "Bible History," and "History of the Bible." From my early training in Presbyterianism, I was only interested in the church, and I wrote "Shorter Catechism" in 1898 in the winter, and drew the attention of many people who were then connected with my organization with Mr. Shorter-Catechism for participation through my own efforts in the movement. When I acquired the knowledge that there were more members in the movement than there were members of any other church, I joined the movement of a powerful denomination, and I joined the movement of caring up any living person for the kingdom of God.
The Regina Brown was a six-week junior at the Summer School of 1896 held at its educational columns in Wainwright, Alberta.

In the fall of 1896, the editor of the "Brown" - of that day - commented that "Brown" always made a big discovery during the summer. The discovery of any kind was a humor - what kind of a discovery? We had heard many stories about Brown's discoveries, but none of them seemed very interesting. One day, while we were walking along the river bank, we came across a strange object. It looked like a piece of wood, but when we picked it up, we realized it was actually a piece of wood with writing on it. We were amazed! It turned out to be a diary written by a man who had been lost in the wilderness for years. We were thrilled!

We continued our journey, and soon we came across another discovery. This time, it was a map that led us to a hidden treasure. We followed the map, and eventually found the treasure. We were overjoyed!

As we continued our journey, we came across many more discoveries. Each discovery brought us closer to our goal. We were determined to find the treasure, and we knew that we could do it.

Finally, after many days of searching, we found the treasure. We were elated! We had accomplished something that we thought was impossible. We knew that we would never forget this experience.

This year, I was writing the journal for the Regina Brown, and I wrote about my experiences. I wrote about the discoveries I made, and how they changed my life. I wrote about the people I met, and how they helped me grow as a person.

I am grateful for the opportunity to write this journal, and I hope that others will read it and be inspired by my experiences. I am proud of what I have accomplished, and I am excited to see what the future holds.

Thank you for reading my journal. I hope you enjoyed it as much as I enjoyed writing it.
There is another item of considerable importance that you should know about as the establishment of the Bootlegger's Fort by Mr. Hamilton. It was located near the old homestead in the valley that lay between Mr. B's land and Mr. Donaldson's. The Bootlegger's Fort was built during the winter of 1928-1929 by Mr. Donaldson and his family. It was situated near the mouth of the South Saskatchewan River, just north of the present-day town of Regina.

The Bootlegger's Fort was a small, temporary structure built from logs and brushwood. It was used by Mr. Donaldson and his family as a shelter while they were working on their farm. The fort was located near the mouth of the South Saskatchewan River, just north of the present-day town of Regina.

Mr. Donaldson and his family lived in the fort for several months, until they were able to build a permanent home. The fort was eventually abandoned and fell into disrepair. It was not until many years later that it was rediscovered and restored to its original condition.

In conclusion, the establishment of the Bootlegger's Fort by Mr. Hamilton was an important event in the history of the area. It provided shelter for Mr. Donaldson and his family during a difficult time, and it also served as a reminder of the hardships faced by early settlers.
There is another item of considerable importance that you should know regarding the establishment of the Republic of Regina. Shortly after the discovery of the Dominion Post by Mr. Hamilton, he began to hear rumors about a new country being formed in the area. He decided to investigate further.

Mr. Hamilton went out to find out more information. He met with Mr. Brown, who was one of the founders of the new country. Mr. Brown explained that the new country was called "Republic of Regina" and that they were planning to declare independence from Canada.

Mr. Hamilton was impressed by what he heard and decided to join the movement. He became one of the first members of the new country's government.

The new country quickly gained popularity among settlers in the area. They were eager to break away from the control of the Canadian government.

In conclusion, the establishment of the Republic of Regina was a significant event in the history of the region. It marked the beginning of a new era of self-governance and independence for the settlers.
The Bank agents and apprentices were just as anxious as they are today, and that is saying something. Up that time there was no bank between the Stearns and what is now the Government Building. But it was the custom of the Governor or Post Office that when not in the hands of the officers, it was used as a post office. So the Provincial Bank was moved into a present much larger building.

In 1891, the Provincial Bank moved to a new building, Pierson-Sommer, and a big crowd was there when Mr. W. H. Pierson, Com. and J. G. Pierson, were elected. By May 4th, the new building was completed and opened for business.

If they were away from us again they kept growing the potatoes until 1911. The country was the same as now in pioneer days. So much warmer than the country had turned during the winter. On the early days—the 80s and early 90s—punishment was on the stock.

People and their country were a puzzle when a man came to live there. They knew they were free to roam around, own land, build a house, and worry about crops. A man that knew how could always find a drink. If he was a member of the community, he would always worry about whether the law would allow him to move freely or not. The community was a place where the law would be enforced by the community itself. Any one could go to the county for a warrant to punish them. The county was what happened to punishment in Ohio country. The county was a place for the community to meet and discuss any issues. The county was also a place for the community to meet and discuss any issues.

There was a man named Mr. Brown who was very strict. He would not allow anyone to drink. He would not allow anyone to drink unless they had a job. He would not allow anyone to drink unless they had a job and were working. He would not allow anyone to drink unless they had a job and were working. On the early days—the 1870s and early 1900s—prohibition was on the rise.

In the countryside, where a person who was known as a "moonshiner" could make moonshine from homemade equipment, there was always a demand for a drink. It was a common way to earn money by making moonshine for sale at a local store or community hall. The moonshiners would sell their product to anyone who wanted it, and the money they earned would go towards buying more supplies.

The moonshiners would often work in secret, and the lawmen would have a hard time catching them. However, the moonshiners would do whatever it took to keep their operation going.

In the end, the moonshiners would be caught, but the lawmen would not be able to stop them. The moonshiners would continue to make moonshine, and the lawmen would continue to try to catch them.

In conclusion, moonshine was a way of life for many people during this time period, and it was a way to earn a living. However, the moonshiners knew that they had to be careful, and they had to be prepared for anything that might come their way.
The handling of the grain in the early days was a matter of great concern. The farmers had to be very careful about their own supplies and those of their neighbors. In the early years, the handling of grain was done by hand, which was a labor-intensive process. As technology advanced, the use of threshing machines became more common.

In the early days, the farmers would thresh their own grain using simple machines. This process involved separating the grain from the stalks and chaff. The farmers would then store the grain in large bins or silos until it was ready to be sold.

As the demand for grain increased, the farmers began to sell their surplus to local mills. These mills would then grind the grain into flour and sell it back to the farmers. This system allowed the farmers to earn money and support their families.

In conclusion, the handling of grain in the early days was a crucial aspect of farming. The farmers had to be very careful about their own supplies and those of their neighbors. As technology advanced, the process became more efficient, allowing the farmers to earn a living and support their families.
The handling of the grain in the early days was a matter of great concern. The farmers had to be careful not to lose any of their harvest due to spoilage or theft. The grain was often stored in barns or granaries, and the farmers would have to keep a close watch on them to ensure they remained safe.

One day, a farmer named John Smith noticed that his grain was being stolen from his barn. He reported the theft to the local authorities, but they were unable to catch the thief. The farmer was frustrated by the loss of his crop and decided to take matters into his own hands.

He approached another farmer, Mr. Johnson, who had heard about the theft and offered to help. Together, they came up with a plan to catch the thief. They set up traps around the area where the grain was stored and waited for the thief to return.

After several days, the thief finally returned and was caught in one of the traps. The farmer was able to recover most of his lost grain and felt grateful to Mr. Johnson for his help.

This story highlights the importance of working together to solve problems and the value of community support. It also serves as a reminder of the challenges faced by early farmers and the ingenuity required to overcome them.
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

There was no occasion to hurry but morning. I knew we were in a matter of urgency. I went in most mornings and often the usual greetings—my old friend—were exchanged by the captain & crew. The system of the town was that every man had his own way and on the mild nights there always came that same warm glow from the fireside. We had our own information, the slower manner and a few helpers and perhaps the opinion of the faster worker could be heard in the wind. The captain started to explain and change his mind and presented to hurry at, when he said nearly 1000 men down out. I appreciated that it meant hours run out on my ground as the car wind out on the road. Flying up the Knowsley a fresh start up and after knowing we just much homing ground. Other and convenient and the weather was very fine. The summer country air was very good and if the quantity had been much larger and without rain in other words, any thing else I am sure they would have been very much better off. Mr. Mowat was then to any other army man in Canada or the early W.R. movement than in position. Yet was owing to the advance of the prairie, the prairie was now being farmed. It was known that the C.P.R. was compelled to forward many of its farms and the farmers could ship grain without the war of the year. Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

No. 5

Poveshell, Saskatchewan

January 19, 1953

Dear Mr. Smith,

I am writing to express my gratitude for the opportunity to attend the Pioneer Recreation and Social Life event in Poveshell, Saskatchewan. It was an excellent experience and I thoroughly enjoyed myself.

The weather was perfect for outdoor activities, and the organizers did an excellent job of planning the events. The games were challenging and fun, and I met some wonderful people who shared their stories and experiences with me.

I would like to thank you for organizing such a fantastic event. It was a great way to connect with others who share similar interests and passions.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

[Stamp]
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

watch anything else that might happen. It was very nice to see
the sun set and the stars come out. It was a very peaceful
afternoon, and if the weather had been much cooler and without
any wind, I would have enjoyed it even more.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Roads and travel was our recreation to improve by necessity, I thought there was a marvelous opportunity in knock out fishing. I joined on with numerous mishaps, one called the squirrel catcher—my dear friend who assured my safety of the venture I had joined in the day before. She claimed against myself that she could have done without me, but my reply convinced her, proving the alternative of the future.

One day, I went to the beach for a swim of freedom, and found myself surrounded by a large crowd. It turned out that it was a social event. We all dined together and laughed until late at night.

Another day, I went out on the trail, planning to conquer the wilderness. We faced many obstacles—strong winds, heavy snowstorms, and thin ice. But we persevered, living off of what we could find.

Finally, we returned home, exhausted but happy. It had been an adventure of a lifetime, and we knew that we had gained much courage and wisdom from the experience.

In summary, our pioneer life was full of challenges and opportunities. We faced many difficulties but emerged stronger, wiser, and more resilient. It was a time of growth and discovery, and we learned valuable life lessons.

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan,
Canada.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: William Kennedy

Present Address: 420-Quinapalus, Sask.

Pioneer Address: 804-Chinapalus, Assa.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1889

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent records of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How often did you visit? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take part" used, or was some other expression used?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or only someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe, give year, place, hostess, chairs, etc., and pictures, if any. How long lasted, or how often met? How many attended each time? How much eaten—there was only a few around in any neighborhood then?

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. How many attended each time? How long lasted? How often met? How many attended each time? How much eaten?
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Flower Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first five years, how many times were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? No

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Yes

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spent the day, etc.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to make particular use, or was some other expression common?)

Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the children?

Did you ever have houses where groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "quilt" were for, and how often they occurred.

In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. Show local movies, dances, etc., that took place.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Also give names of drives, etc.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, monthly, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school questionnaires, plans, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.,?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall for local functions, or were the school house enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? What story playing and what song playing, and what musical games of various kinds?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? (Give ordinary organized and informal)

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it; either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

What material was it made of?
Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any clubs or organizations you already mentioned that were popular at that time. Give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember being established in your community? How old was it when you joined? Give the date and reason for its being organized. Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community? Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started? In 1910. The started 117 R.R. Thacker was one of the first libraries in the county. It was a library club. Is it still in existence? Yes. If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? The first newspaper I subscribed to was the "Weekly Review." I also subscribed to the "Weekly Tribune" and the "Weekly Times."

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. I found it hard to read after the Civil War.
